texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I  aired my grievances  about Ooma's phone service recently on my  Mastodon account . They require you to call them to cancel and then their convoluted cancellation process spins you in circles. Luckily I had a prepaid credit card with a dollar or two left on it and I used that as my primary billing card. Problem solved. 👏
texts.text: I  aired my grievances  about Ooma's phone service recently on my  Mastodon account . They require you to call them to cancel and then their convoluted cancellation process spins you in circles. Luckily I had a prepaid credit card with a dollar or two left on it and I used that as my primary billing card. Problem solved. 👏

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Later in the Mastodon thread, I mentioned how my replacement solution costs 85 cents a month and someone asked me how I do it. It's not the easiest process. However, once you get it working, it doesn't require much upkeep.
texts.text: Later in the Mastodon thread, I mentioned how my replacement solution costs 85 cents a month and someone asked me how I do it. It's not the easiest process. However, once you get it working, it doesn't require much upkeep.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: But before we start...
texts.text: But before we start...

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Who the heck needs a home phone in 2023?
texts.text: Who the heck needs a home phone in 2023?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Yes, this is a common question I get. Mobile phones, tablets, and laptops all have so much communication connectivity now that home phones aren't really relevant.
texts.text: Yes, this is a common question I get. Mobile phones, tablets, and laptops all have so much communication connectivity now that home phones aren't really relevant.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I like having one around for my kids to use and it's nice to have a backup in case there are issues with the mobile phone networks. One of my kids has a mobile phone and the other does not. It also allows my neighbors' kids (who may or may not have phones of their own) to call their parents at any time.
texts.text: I like having one around for my kids to use and it's nice to have a backup in case there are issues with the mobile phone networks. One of my kids has a mobile phone and the other does not. It also allows my neighbors' kids (who may or may not have phones of their own) to call their parents at any time.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: 85 cents a month?
texts.text: 85 cents a month?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We're talking $0.85 USD per month. For real. That price covers a direct inbound dialing (DID) number in various area codes throughout the USA. Some countries might have different pricing, but this works in the USA.
texts.text: We're talking $0.85 USD per month. For real. That price covers a direct inbound dialing (DID) number in various area codes throughout the USA. Some countries might have different pricing, but this works in the USA.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You might be wondering if there are additional costs. Well, yes, there are.
texts.text: You might be wondering if there are additional costs. Well, yes, there are.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Outbound calls are $0.01 per minute and inbound calls are $0.009 per minute. That would leave you with a bill of about $10.85 for 1,000 minutes  (just under 17 hours of calls) .
texts.text: Outbound calls are $0.01 per minute and inbound calls are $0.009 per minute. That would leave you with a bill of about $10.85 for 1,000 minutes  (just under 17 hours of calls) .

texts.label: title
texts.orig: What's involved?
texts.text: What's involved?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When you get a phone call on your mobile phone, this is what happens:
texts.text: When you get a phone call on your mobile phone, this is what happens:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Someone dials your number from their phone
texts.text: Someone dials your number from their phone

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ✨ Magic ✨
texts.text: ✨ Magic ✨

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your phone rings and you can pick it up
texts.text: Your phone rings and you can pick it up

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For this home phone solution, it goes something like this:
texts.text: For this home phone solution, it goes something like this:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You buy a DID number from a VOIP provider
texts.text: You buy a DID number from a VOIP provider

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You connect a SIP phone, an ATA device, or your phone/computer to a SIP endpoint
texts.text: You connect a SIP phone, an ATA device, or your phone/computer to a SIP endpoint

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Someone calls your DID number
texts.text: Someone calls your DID number

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Something'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Something'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I say  something  here because it can be anything. An old telephone with a cradle, wireless DECT phones, fancy SIP phones, or a computer.
texts.text: I say  something  here because it can be anything. An old telephone with a cradle, wireless DECT phones, fancy SIP phones, or a computer.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: SIP phones  are phones that connect directly to a network via ethernet or wi-fi. You configure a SIP account on the device itself and it connects to your VOIP provider, registers itself, and waits for inbound or outbound calls.
texts.text: SIP phones  are phones that connect directly to a network via ethernet or wi-fi. You configure a SIP account on the device itself and it connects to your VOIP provider, registers itself, and waits for inbound or outbound calls.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: ATA devices  are analog telephone adapters that translate the modern world of VOIP for a regular old phone. This allows you to take existing cordless phones (or corded phones) and connect them to a VOIP account. For these devices, you normally access the ATA via a web interface and configure them.
texts.text: ATA devices  are analog telephone adapters that translate the modern world of VOIP for a regular old phone. This allows you to take existing cordless phones (or corded phones) and connect them to a VOIP account. For these devices, you normally access the ATA via a web interface and configure them.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: SIP phone vs. ATA
texts.text: SIP phone vs. ATA

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I chose ATA devices because they're cheaper to buy, easy to maintain, and you can use anything with them that has a phone jack. Got Grandma's old red phone with a cradle? It works. Got a cordless DECT multi-phone system with an answering machine? It works.
texts.text: I chose ATA devices because they're cheaper to buy, easy to maintain, and you can use anything with them that has a phone jack. Got Grandma's old red phone with a cradle? It works. Got a cordless DECT multi-phone system with an answering machine? It works.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As long as it does tone dialing, you're set.  (Let's not bring pulse dialing into this, please.)
texts.text: As long as it does tone dialing, you're set.  (Let's not bring pulse dialing into this, please.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The challenge with these is that they're not being manufactured that often lately. Mobile phones have really pushed these devices to the corners of the market. Most VOIP equipment is aimed at big businesses and these small devices can be hard to find.
texts.text: The challenge with these is that they're not being manufactured that often lately. Mobile phones have really pushed these devices to the corners of the market. Most VOIP equipment is aimed at big businesses and these small devices can be hard to find.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My current favorite is the  Grandstream HT801 . It supports only phone phone line, so get the HT802 if you need two lines at home.
texts.text: My current favorite is the  Grandstream HT801 . It supports only phone phone line, so get the HT802 if you need two lines at home.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The device has a port for power, an ethernet port, and phone line port. That's all you need. Plug the phone into the phone line port, connect the ethernet port to your router or switch, and you're set!
texts.text: The device has a port for power, an ethernet port, and phone line port. That's all you need. Plug the phone into the phone line port, connect the ethernet port to your router or switch, and you're set!

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Getting a phone number
texts.text: Getting a phone number

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My favorite VOIP service is  voip.ms . Their prices are reasonable, their control panel is easy to use, and they have lots of business functions that you can use for free (such as an IVR, which is a "press 1 for sales" menu system).
texts.text: My favorite VOIP service is  voip.ms . Their prices are reasonable, their control panel is easy to use, and they have lots of business functions that you can use for free (such as an IVR, which is a "press 1 for sales" menu system).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After you set up an account on voip.ms and deposit some money, go to  DID Numbers  and click  Order DID . You get lots of options of numbers to buy including international numbers.  (If you have family overseas who would like to call you as a local call from their phone, this could be a great option!)
texts.text: After you set up an account on voip.ms and deposit some money, go to  DID Numbers  and click  Order DID . You get lots of options of numbers to buy including international numbers.  (If you have family overseas who would like to call you as a local call from their phone, this could be a great option!)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For US numbers, you'll then get a menu asking you to pick a state and then pick numbers. You can also look for numbers that contain a set of numbers (including the area code). These are helpful if you want to spell something with your number (young kids have no idea what fun this used to be) or get something that's easy to remember.
texts.text: For US numbers, you'll then get a menu asking you to pick a state and then pick numbers. You can also look for numbers that contain a set of numbers (including the area code). These are helpful if you want to spell something with your number (young kids have no idea what fun this used to be) or get something that's easy to remember.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You'll get two options for paying for the number:
texts.text: You'll get two options for paying for the number:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: One option is a flat rate all-you-can-eat plan, usually for $3-$10 monthly. This might
texts.text: One option is a flat rate all-you-can-eat plan, usually for $3-$10 monthly. This might

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Another option will be the $0.85/month option where you pay extra for all calls. This
texts.text: Another option will be the $0.85/month option where you pay extra for all calls. This

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Complete the remaining steps you'll have your number!
texts.text: Complete the remaining steps you'll have your number!

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Create a sub account
texts.text: Create a sub account

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The voip.ms system has a concept of "sub-accounts" where you have individual SIP logins for each device.  This is highly recommended for security reasons.
texts.text: The voip.ms system has a concept of "sub-accounts" where you have individual SIP logins for each device.  This is highly recommended for security reasons.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Click the  Sub Accounts  menu and then  Create Sub Account . Set up your password and choose from the options around allowing international calls and how you want your calls routed. Most of the defaults are fine here.
texts.text: Click the  Sub Accounts  menu and then  Create Sub Account . Set up your password and choose from the options around allowing international calls and how you want your calls routed. Most of the defaults are fine here.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The username/password combination is the one you'll use for your ATA later, so be sure to remember those.
texts.text: The username/password combination is the one you'll use for your ATA later, so be sure to remember those.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Connecting the DID and sub account
texts.text: Connecting the DID and sub account

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Go back to the  DID Numbers  menu and click  Manage DIDs . Find the number you bought and look for the orange pencil underneath the  Actions  heading. When the page loads, make a few changes:
texts.text: Go back to the  DID Numbers  menu and click  Manage DIDs . Find the number you bought and look for the orange pencil underneath the  Actions  heading. When the page loads, make a few changes:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: First, look for the
texts.text: First, look for the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Under the
texts.text: Under the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Under
texts.text: Under

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You have an option for enabling SMS/MMS for an additional fee, but it's not terribly
texts.text: You have an option for enabling SMS/MMS for an additional fee, but it's not terribly

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Apply the changes at the bottom of the page. Now you're all set to connect your phones or ATA device!
texts.text: Apply the changes at the bottom of the page. Now you're all set to connect your phones or ATA device!

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Adding an ATA
texts.text: Adding an ATA

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: voip.ms has a  massive page  full of information about nearly every ATA they support. There are configuration instructions in a link under each device that give you tips on how to best configure your device.
texts.text: voip.ms has a  massive page  full of information about nearly every ATA they support. There are configuration instructions in a link under each device that give you tips on how to best configure your device.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you picked up an HT801/HT802 like I recommended, you can go straight to the HT802  configuration guide. The instructions there work just fine for the HT801, too.
texts.text: If you picked up an HT801/HT802 like I recommended, you can go straight to the HT802  configuration guide. The instructions there work just fine for the HT801, too.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Make sure your ATA device is powered on and plugged into your home ethernet network (or wi-fi if it is so equipped). You can get the IP address for your ATA device by checking DHCP leases on your router or you can pick up your phone connected to the ATA and press asterisk/star (*) three times. A friendly computer voice will tell you the IP address of the ATA device.
texts.text: Make sure your ATA device is powered on and plugged into your home ethernet network (or wi-fi if it is so equipped). You can get the IP address for your ATA device by checking DHCP leases on your router or you can pick up your phone connected to the ATA and press asterisk/star (*) three times. A friendly computer voice will tell you the IP address of the ATA device.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Follow the configuration instructions to the letter!  Some of these settings, especially for audio codecs, are critical for getting high quality, reliable phone calls.
texts.text: Follow the configuration instructions to the letter!  Some of these settings, especially for audio codecs, are critical for getting high quality, reliable phone calls.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's time to make phone calls once you've configured your device! You should be able to dial out from your home phone and receive calls on the same number. If you can make calls but can't receive calls, double check that your sub account shows  Registered on the voip.ms  portal home page . If it doesn't appear as Registered  in green, then voip.ms has no way to tell your device there's a phone call coming.
texts.text: It's time to make phone calls once you've configured your device! You should be able to dial out from your home phone and receive calls on the same number. If you can make calls but can't receive calls, double check that your sub account shows  Registered on the voip.ms  portal home page . If it doesn't appear as Registered  in green, then voip.ms has no way to tell your device there's a phone call coming.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Go back and double check your account username and password. Also verify that your ATA configuration matches  exactly  to the recommended configuration provided by voip.ms.
texts.text: Go back and double check your account username and password. Also verify that your ATA configuration matches  exactly  to the recommended configuration provided by voip.ms.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Extra credit
texts.text: Extra credit

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Although I get a  very  small number of spam calls and robocalls on my voip.ms DID, there's a chance your experience might be different.
texts.text: Although I get a  very  small number of spam calls and robocalls on my voip.ms DID, there's a chance your experience might be different.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: voip.ms offers quite a few services to help here, especially  CallerID Filtering . You can block anonymous calls or callers who have their CallerID marked as unavailable.
texts.text: voip.ms offers quite a few services to help here, especially  CallerID Filtering . You can block anonymous calls or callers who have their CallerID marked as unavailable.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's also pretty easy to set up a  Digital Receiptionist (IVR)  where you can make callers press a number or jump through a hoop or two before your phone rings. Once you create your IVR, run back to DID Numbers  and then  Manage DIDs  to change your routing settings to use the new IVR. (Look for  IVR  just under  SIP/IAX  on the DID settings page.)
texts.text: It's also pretty easy to set up a  Digital Receiptionist (IVR)  where you can make callers press a number or jump through a hoop or two before your phone rings. Once you create your IVR, run back to DID Numbers  and then  Manage DIDs  to change your routing settings to use the new IVR. (Look for  IVR  just under  SIP/IAX  on the DID settings page.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Before you celebrate, be sure to turn on  automatic billing ! You can tell voip.ms to fill your account with some money when it crosses a certain threshold. I have mine set to add $25 each time I drop under $10. They will send you nag emails as soon as your balance gets low but you don't want to forget about it.
texts.text: Before you celebrate, be sure to turn on  automatic billing ! You can tell voip.ms to fill your account with some money when it crosses a certain threshold. I have mine set to add $25 each time I drop under $10. They will send you nag emails as soon as your balance gets low but you don't want to forget about it.
